awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EAGER--Effect of Eddy Forcing Induced by Eyewall and Rainband Convection on Tropical Cyclone Rapid Intensification
awd_abstract_narration:
The research seeks to advance our understanding of internal dynamics in governing Tropical Cyclone (TC) intensification and improve forecasting skills for rapid change of TC intensity. The results and products of this project can be immediately implemented in operational models for TC prediction, disseminated to the broader TC modeling community, and used in Principal Investigator (PI)'s course teaching in TC theories and applications. The project supports a postdoctoral researcher.  The educational goal of the project is to train and educate the next generation of scientists with the engagement of postdoctoral researcher and graduate/undergraduate students.

The conventional view of Tropical Cyclone (TC) intensification regards the absolute angular momentum as a materially conserved quantity above the friction layer.  This study seeks to demonstrate that the eddy process associated with eyewall and rainband convection serves as a sole forcing for the azimuthal-mean angular momentum conservation.  It is this forcing that provides an ultimate mechanism for triggering and driving Rapid Intensification (RI) of TCs that cannot be explained by the classic TC intensification theories.  At the current resolution of operational models, the PIs demonstrate that the sub-grid scale (SGS) forcing above the PBL associated with convection poses an important bearing on TC intensification, especially RI.  How to generate a realistic SGS forcing aloft in the TC inner-core region is a new challenge in turbulent mixing parameterization that has not been previously explored.  The most important features of this EAGER project are: (1) advance our understanding of the role of eddy forcing associated with eyewall and rainband convection in modulating intensity change of TCs and (2) develop physically robust parameterization to represent sub-grid scale forcing associated with convection above the PBL in numerical models used for TC prediction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Turbulence is commonly regarded as a flow feature pertaining to the boundary layer, the lowest layer of the atmosphere. In fair-weather conditions, the turbulent boundary layer is cleanly separated from the free atmosphere above by a capping inversion. In the inner core of a tropical cyclone (TC), turbulence can also be generated above the boundary layer by cloud processes. The characteristics of turbulence and vertical thermodynamic structure in the eyewall and rainbands of a TC are in stark different from those in fair-weather conditions. Moreover, as the boundary layer flow moves inward and approaches the radius of maximum wind (RMW), the boundary layer becomes ill defined as the air is pulled up into the eyewall. Because of the unique dynamic, thermodynamic, and turbulence structure in TC inner-core, questions remain as to how the turbulent processes in TC inner-core affect the TC intensification and how they can be realistically parameterized in numerical models. Thus, the goals of this project are to (1) improve sub-grid scale (SGS) turbulent mixing parameterization to better represent the turbulent transport and the associated dynamical-turbulent-microphysical interaction in TC inner-core and (2) advance our understanding of the role of eyewall turbulent transport in modulating TC intensification.  

Airborne radar observations (Lorsolo et al. 2010; Zhu et al. 2019) and large eddy simulations (Li et al. 2022) show that the turbulent kinetic energy (TKE) extends well above the boundary layer in the eyewall where no physical interface, such as inversion, exists to separate the turbulence generated by the boundary layer processes and cloud processes aloft. However, the Eddy-Diffusivity-Mass-Flux (EDMF) hybrid planetary boundary layer (PBL) scheme (Han et al. 2016) used in the operational Hurricane Weather Research & Forecasting (HWRF) model parameterizes the turbulence within and above the boundary layer separately based on a diagnosed PBL height. This separated parameterization fails to capture the intense turbulent mixing generated in the eyewall clouds. By defining a ?turbulent layer (TL)? that envelops the turbulence generated by both boundary layer and cloud processes, we explicitly include the in-cloud turbulent mixing the HWRF?s PBL scheme. The numerical experiments from 119 simulation cycles of hurricanes in 2016-2017 seasons show that the modified PBL scheme substantially reduces the bias error of the forecasted maximum wind speed (Fig. 1, Zhu et al. 2019).

Our analyses reveal that the Hurricane Analysis and Forecast System (HAFS), a new multi-scale Unified Forecast System (UFS) model, is unable to capture the intense turbulent mixing above the boundary layer in the eyewall due to a poor estimation of static stability in clouds. The problem is solved by including the effects of multi-phase water (vapor, liquid and solid hydrometeors) in the stability calculation. Simulations of 21 TCs and tropical storm totaling 118 forecast cycles show that the stability correction in HAFS?s PBL scheme substantially improves HAFS?s skill in predicting storm track, intensity, and structure (Fig. 2, Zhu et al. 2021).

Using model output, we investigated why the better parameterized turbulent transport in the eyewall leads to the improved forecasting skill of storm track, intensity, and structure by HWRF and HAFS, and the role of eyewall turbulent transport in TC intensification. The analyses show that the radially inward transport of absolute vorticity by the mean radial inflow is the main driving force for the TC vortex acceleration consistent with the boundary-layer spin-up mechanism proposed by Smith et al. (2009). The improved parameterization of SGS turbulent transport above the boundary layer in the eyewall results in a more robust dynamical-turbulent-microphysical interaction in eyewall clouds and plays a pivotal role in initiating a positive feedback among the eyewall convection, mean secondary circulation, vortex acceleration via the inward transport of absolute vorticity, surface evaporation, and radial convergence of moisture in the boundary layer underlying the TC intensification, in particular, rapid intensification (Zhu et al. 2021).

In this project, we also investigated issues regarding the parameterization of turbulent transport in TC inner-core using TKE turbulent mixing schemes as the approach provides an ideal framework for parameterizing the turbulence generated by the boundary layer and cloud processes in a unified manner regardless of the PBL height. In addition to the TKE generated by eyewall clouds, the analyses of numerical simulations and in-situ aircraft measurements show that the lateral entrainment of moat air into the eyewall by the cloud induced turbulence meets the instability criterion, causing the entrained air to sink unstably. This mechanism of TKE generation in the eyewall due to the positive lateral entrainment buoyancy flux needs to be included in the buoyancy production of TKE in the TKE turbulent mixing scheme used for treating the turbulent transport in the inner core of TCs.
